key_points: On January 6, rioters stormed the US Capitol, leading to a significant insurrection.
Missed warnings, insufficient preparation, and leadership failures contributed to the chaos.
1,200 US Capitol Police officers were on duty, but some could not access riot gear due to it being locked in buses.
73 Capitol Police and 65 DC Metropolitan Police officers were injured, with one death reported.
Violent plans were made public online prior to the riot, with groups such as QAnon and the Proud Boys openly discussing coordination.
US Capitol Police received warnings but failed to act effectively due to poor information sharing and underestimation of the threats.
The Capitol Police did not have a department-wide plan for the day, and many officers were not adequately equipped.
Communication failures left officers feeling abandoned during the riot.
Bureaucracy delayed the National Guard response, which did not arrive until hours after the riot began.
A Senate report offered recommendations to prevent future incidents and criticized the Capitol Police's preparedness and response.
